options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: None
Virtual seminar.
This course was a live zoom course throughout.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: A grounding in the work of Black feminist theory and an introduction to the major scholars and anthropologists doing work on the intersectional oppression of women.

Through the many books we read in this class, I was able to think about and discuss issues of women's health in many different ways with a focus on intersectionality - especially as someone who is premed, I feel that I got incredibly important insights into the ways in which women with various different intersecting identities have been historically and continue to be abused or mistreated by the US medical system.

A strong background on the American medical system's failures with regards to minority communities, and an appreciation for all the ways in which practicing medicine can still cause harm within that system

This class had extremely interesting readings, and although they were whole books, it never felt like a chore. I think I developed a more robust understanding of Back feminist theory, reproductive justice, as well as medical anthropology. The readings and discussions were both enjoyable and stimulating.

As I am a student of architecture, this course helped me to understand many of the women's reproductive health issues in the US- especially for the black and brown women. My book review skills have improved vastly and my general writing skills also have improved thanks to this class.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Nothing weak about this course, its perfect

The class is very well structured, so it would suit students who are interested in having highly organized seminar discussions. The assignments are likewise well organized, with a blueprint available for each book review. The ethnographies are well-selected, though I do wish there were discussions of aspects of womens health that are not always about their reproductive health.

The course is excellent and the diversity of topics that we covered was really great.  I think that finding an ethnography about queer womxn to read as a class would be a great addition, but it seems like that's more of a problem with a lack of existing literature than with the class itself.

Strengths: Very interesting course material, Professor Inhorn obviously is very interested and knowledgeable on the subject matter, and her excitement also seeps into the course. Everyone has the opportunity to go into depth about their more niche interests by leading seminar for a day. 
Weaknesses: The grading seems a little harsh, but the comments are all very useful nonetheless.
This is a very strong class and its highly interactive sessions (with student presentations and dialogues) were very helpful in reviewing our readings.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think the course was adjusted well for Zoom.
I think the seminar was very conducive to learning during the pandemic, but I can't speak for those without highspeed internet.
The class was great the way it was.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: To be honest, who wouldnt? This course was phenomenal.

Definitely, its not necessarily an easy course (reading load is somewhat heavy  a book a week) but the discussions are very interesting and its important that people be exposed to the work of scholars of intersectionality.

Yes, with the caveat that the course is definitely a lot of reading, and taking this class really requires committing to that.  Only take this course if you're ready to engage deeply with the material, but if you decide to, it is absolutely worth it and Marcia is wonderful!

If you are premed, this course should be a requirementthere's no excuse for going into medicine without knowing about the history of the system you're stepping yourself into and the ways in which that system has harmed and continues to harm women and minorities. Even if you're premed, you should take the class anyways because Marcia is an incredible professor who cares deeply about the students and about the material she teaches.
Yes! It was genuinely enjoyable to take. Professor Inhorn is passionate about the subject matter, and you do learn a lot.
Yes, I would recommend this course to those students interested in feminist studies as a way to widen their perspective.
